Commit Message: Initial commit
Initial commit

Implement ssh server ourselves

The asyncssh project is wonderful. Implementing our own
ssh server was easy. We can control authentication and spawning
much better in our own implementation, unlikein OpenSSH.

Allow sshing in with no explicit command

This fixes double echoing of stdin to stdout.

Do not crash process when argument parsing fails

The world is filled with random scanners that will try to
ssh into your boxes for you. This prevents kubessh from crashing
when one of them tries a random command.

Add daemon to clean up completed pods

When a user shell exits, the pod goes into 'Complete' state.
This does not *seem* to be removed by autoscaler - that
needs more testing. In the meantime, we have a separate
daemon that just cleans up completed pods every 30s.

Will try to keep functionality like this split into different
processes that do not share memory, to keep life simple for
everyone. Let's try do *all* our state storage in k8s objects.

Fixes #15

Random hacking around to see what I can do with socat

I had strung together a way to do 'direct' TCP connections as:

KubeSSH -> socat (stdio) -> kubectl exec (stdio, websocket, socat) -> socat -> target

This has several advantages:

1. RBAC for auth
2. KubeSSH and User Pod don't need to be on same network
3. Easy to reason about

And many disadvantages:

1. Absolutely terrible performance
2. This is nuts

I decided to use kubectl port-forward instead of kubectl exec, since
port-forard uses socat in the background to do the thing I'm trying to
do. In the future, there should be a different backend that just uses
network connections. Until then...

Use kubectl port-forward to implement direct tcp connections

- Runs a single kubectl port-forward process per eonnection
  request, and uses asyncio to push traffic to it
- This uses socat in the background, but all the bugs and
  settings are handled for us automaticlaly by kubectl
- We are still sending TCP over websocket, which is a PITA
  performance-wise. But that's SSH already anyway.
- WORKS WITH VSCODE!
- Needs tests
Add simpervisor as a requirement

Use deterministic pod names

We were using labels + selectors to determine which user
was on which pod. This is extremely useful when you have many
pods per user. However, we do not support that yet. We also need
to make a netwrok call to figure out name of pod - something needed
for port-forward and exec.

So we go back to the JupyterHub tactic of using a predictable
pod name, so we can get it without having to hit the network.

Handle port-forward processes properly

Add a FIXME, remove a FIXME

Use same logger throughout application

Before this, each class seems to be getting its own logger
object, without inheriting the parent's logging config.
This seems to not match my experience with other apps
using traitlets, but that's ok. Passing 'log' explicilty
to instance creation does what I want. Without it,
a new 'traitlet' logger was created for each class,
and it didn't have appropriate level set - causing the
logging messages to be swallowed.

fix crash on window size change

See https://github.com/yuvipanda/kubessh/issues/18

add rudimentary Gitlab authenticator

Add a basic Gitlab authenticator that allows all public keys users have added to
their account, just like the Github one; the only difference for now is the
ability to specify a URL to a self-hosted Gitlab instance. Future API-based
functionality may be worthwile, such as allowing access control via Gitlab user
groups.

gitlab-auth: default to gitlab.com instance and add allowed_users

Use the public gitlab.com by default. Add an allowed_users setting that defaults
to disallowing all users, but can be configured to allow every user of the
gitlab instance

add capability to create PersistentVolumeClaims along with user Pods

add a new values.yaml key 'pvcTemplates' that specifies a list of
PersistentVolumeClaims to create along with user pods. Example usage:

  pvcTemplates:
  - kind: PersistentVolumeClaim
    apiVersion: v1
    metadata:
      name: kubessh-homedir-{username}
    spec:
      accessModes:
        - ReadWriteOnce
      resources:
        requests:
          storage: 32Gi
      storageClassName: ceph-rbd

The referenced storage class must previously have been configured in the
kubernetes cluster.
